comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: It does seem that a war of words was happening in February, 1915 (where the photo is in the Bain flow), so I think it's more likely that the caption was written then. From the Wikipedia article on HMS Lusitania: "1915 The official warning issued by the Imperial German Embassy about travelling on Lusitania. By early 1915 a new threat began to materialize: submarines. At first they were used by the Germans only to attack naval vessels, and they achieved only occasional – but sometimes spectacular – successes. Then the U-boats began to attack merchant vessels at times, although almost always in accordance with the old cruiser rules. Desperate to gain an advantage on the Atlantic, the German government decided to step up their submarine campaign. On 4 February 1915 Germany declared the seas around the British Isles a war zone: from 18 February allied ships in the area would be sunk without warning." This was not wholly unrestricted submarine warfare since efforts would be taken to avoid sinking neutral ships." It is definitely ironic that this very ship (under a French flag and named La Dives) was sunk by the Germans in January, 1918. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Lusitania#International_reaction

Could be.  The entire Bain collection thus far is captioned in the same block printing, so I assumed somebody cataloged it all at a later date.  But it's just as likely that the same person worked there for years and cataloged it as it was created.  (Maybe the LOC knows for sure...?)

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: From what I understand, the negative would be hand-lettered and numbered first, so that the prints sent out to Bain's news photo subscribers would have basic caption info and an ID number handy as part of the image. We have a card catalog with hand-written entries made by Bain staff, but they are a subject index to the negatives, and it seems likely that the entries were added after the prints were made. As an example, the top of the card might say Christmas and below that is a list of inked numbers for negatives related to that topic. (I'll check next week at the Library and see if I can find which subject card listed this negative and post it here.) We also have a set of caption cards typed by LOC staff 40-50 years ago when they went through the negatives systematically. They combined and often shortened info found on the negative, the old paper sleeve for the negative, and the subject index. These typed cards are the source for the current captions you see in Flickr, even with their typos. It's been great to have a "positive" version of the negative (the digitized image) and the caption card info side-by-side now for easier comparison. We change the caption titles now to match what's written on the negatives. Best of all, we can add the fuller names and subject info that you all provide to the records, too! -- Helena (LOC)
